content.definition: Surgical removal of the great or small saphenous vein for treatment of varicose veins and chronic venous insufficiency. Traditional open surgery that has largely been replaced by endovenous ablation (RFA, laser) but remains relevant when ablation is not feasible or has failed.

technique.high_ligation: Groin incision, ligation of SFJ with tributaries
technique.stripping: Pass stripper from groin to knee (or ankle), remove vein en bloc

indications: GSV/SSV reflux when ablation not feasible
Superficial or tortuous veins (catheter cannot pass)

outcomes.healing: Ulcer healing rates comparable to ablation
outcomes.recovery: Longer than ablation (1-2 weeks vs days)

complications: Saphenous nerve injury (paresthesia if stripped to ankle)

comparison_to_ablation.stripping: More invasive, longer recovery, equally effective
comparison_to_ablation.ablation: Less invasive, faster recovery, becoming standard

clinical_pearls: Strip to knee only - reduces saphenous nerve injury
High ligation alone has high recurrence - must address GSV
Endovenous ablation now first-line; stripping is fallback
Neovascularization at SFJ is main cause of recurrence

learning_objectives: Describe technique of saphenous vein stripping
Identify indications where stripping preferred over ablation
Understand complications and how to avoid them
